Were you mainly women there again?
Yes, yes. The men were either in the tool makers or in the machine shop, but the men were over us, mind.
You always had a man, but like the manager was a man mostly, but yeah, I've always worked with women.
What about the shop stewards, were they women or men?
Men, some of them were men, but men ran mostly things, you know.
Men was the top and they had a few women shop stewards.
Do you remember about holidays? Do you remember about holidays there then?
Same again, it was two weeks with the miners, two days Christmas, mostly two days for the bird banks.
No weeks, never weeks, but you got used to that.
And sometimes you'd have a Saturday morning, you'd pick up a bit more money and things like that.
You know, that was alright then, you know, a little bit more. Everybody's glad of that, aren't they?
So you had overtime then?
Sometimes, yeah.
Only sometimes? Do you know why?
When they'd have an order or something, you know.
Did you have...
Yeah, I'd done the Beatles, didn't I? The Beatles, didn't they make their records or something when they came in?
Paliphone, was that it?
Yeah, because I remember having a bit of a boner through the Beatles. Yeah.
In what way, how did that affect you then?
I don't know. I don't know if it was the first or second I remember, but I remember that we had something then because the Beatles made all this money.
They must have, what do you call it, an MC, isn't it?
What did you actually make then? What was the end product?
I think it was the second, I can't remember.
Do you remember the Ernie? The premium bond used to pick the Ernie. They'd done the machine for that the one time.
Yeah, and we had to go through it. Oh, solder different colour wires to different points and all that.
Yeah, and we were all doing a big part of the whole thing was the Ernie for the premium bond.
Right, I remember that, yes.
So the Ernie was one thing, but what else did you do?
I don't know what that little course was for, I can't remember. I didn't mind, not that. I don't know what it was for. It was part of something.
Did you used to make record players?
Yes, yeah.
Do you remember what kind of record players?
Well, I only remember the speaker and the motor, I don't know what they actually went into, you know. They must have been selling them to a lot of big names, you know.
So it was only a part of it?
Yeah, I was balancing the router, which was the core of the motor. And then we were doing, I was working on the motor section, you know, and then the speaker section.
So it was all for record players and different things like that, wasn't it?
So how did you feel when you were told that you had a bonus because of the Beatles?
Oh, the Beatles, yes. Because they were, oh, I thought they were fabulous when they came out, weren't they? Yeah, everybody was so excited about that. Yeah.
Did it make you feel a part of the whole thing?
Yes, it felt as if you knew one more, like, you know. Because, I mean, we were only from a little place and that's all up in the whole England, like, you know. Yeah, I remember that. Oh, the Beatles.
Part of the swinging sixes, yeah.
Yeah, they were swinging, weren't they? Started it all off. Flour Power and all that, weren't they?
I remember when a cow's bell rang my neck, oh, my friend fetched it. That's in the EMI. She went somewhere and she came back with these cow bell. You know, the cow bell. I remember that.
You talked about your friendships with people in EMI. Can you tell me a little bit more about the camaraderie between the women, that kind of thing? Did you go out socially?
Yes, I did. I got on lovely with them in EMI. My good friend, like I say, I see him today. I don't actually go out to them, but you always remember, you know, you work together and there's that bond and I find anyway.
Did you go out with them then though? Yes, yeah. Where did you used to go? We used to go to Shaq, Pentreligion, whenever they called it, the Shaq. Everybody went to Shaq when they were a certain age.
And then we used to go to the Alex first, when it started. I think I was a bit underage really, but I got away with it because I looked older. And then we'd run up by half past nine to the Shaq. I'd have to be in by half past nine.
They wouldn't even win if you were after half past nine. What happened in the Shaq then? Dancing and you met people there. Most people met their future husbands and all that there, you know.
What was the music like? What kind of music? Rock and roll. And the skirts with the net and the American tan and the stockings and all them petty guts.
You used to stiffen them up with sugar and water and anything that would make them stick out and ballerina shoes. And cardigans back to front in a black straight skirt. You never had much, you know.
You used to have a black skirt where you were stable and you used to have a cardigan with the buttons in the back and then raw pearls. I think you was it. Fabulous.
So tell me about, was it live music then? Yes, yes. Was it a local band? Local band, yes. Did they play every week? Yes, I remember. They were good, so you know.
Do you remember what the name was? No. Did they make any records? It was a little bit before the rock and roll when it first started going in there. But then it was records mostly after then with the rock and roll, wasn't it? Yeah.
So did the company put on dos? Yes. Now again they'd have a dos. I remember going to EMI DOS. Where did you go? In the canteen. Oh in the work? Yes, in the canteen.
So what kind of do was that then? Dancing and a bit of buffet if I remember right. Nothing elaborate but you liked it. And was that in the evening then? Yeah.
Was that for Christmas? Yes, mostly individual Christmas dos though, section by section, you'd organise it yourself. They never put nothing on for you.
Right. Where did you go for Christmas dos then? Christmas dos, I can't remember. Labour club? Labour club, you know, anywhere where you could, I remember going to the den, they used to have a nice room in the back there.
Places like that we went, you know. You could book a room anywhere and they'd put a meal on and then you know, all your own money, mine. Another factory's ever done anything like that.
Then it was the Jews they'd have, it was the union mostly who would put on in the canteen, now and again. But Christmas was individual sections, you know.
Were there any perks from working in EMI? No, not really. You paid for what you'd done, I can now say, yeah. You bought your own season to get, your own uniform. Yeah, didn't have very much.
Do you remember how many of you worked there? You were talking about different sections, now. I would think it was about a thousand plus more, you know.
Because it had really come into its own at that time with that, doing that electronic and all that, you know. And where was it exactly, EMI? In Pentle, isn't it? No talkie, talkie.
I also worked in the Rayavac making batteries behind there. It was the same, that was an American place, but it was all coming under EMI. What was it called, sorry? Rayavac.
And when did you work there? Well, I went after any EMI. I went away, me and my sister went to Living Winchester. We thought we'd go away and try it, didn't we?
And I ended up twisting sausage in a factory there, now then. And then there was somebody at the end of the line cutting the end, like, oh no, come on. That was really, didn't stay there long.
And I went away, where did I go then? What did I say? Rayavac. Making batteries. So you came back to play, didn't you? Yes.
